This happens because the orbital plane slowly precesses (rotates) eastward at about 1° per day — exactly matching the rate at which Earth orbits the Sun over the course of a year. As a result, the satellite's relationship to the Sun stays constant year-round, providing consistent lighting conditions underneath it. Why is this useful? Earth-observing satellites (weather, reconnaissance, Landsat, Sentinel) benefit from near-identical sunlight angles on every pass → easier to compare images over time, detect changes, etc. Infrared or visible imaging gets reliable illumination without big seasonal variations in shadow or brightness. Dawn-dusk (or twilight) variant Many SSOs are tuned to a dawn-dusk configuration, where the satellite crosses the equator near local sunrise or sunset (~6 AM or 6 PM local time). The spacecraft essentially "rides" along the terminator (the day-night boundary line). Key advantages of this specific type: The satellite stays almost continuously in sunlight → solar panels get near-constant power, with minimal or zero time in Earth's shadow (great for power-hungry payloads or missions avoiding eclipses). This is especially valuable for certain astronomy or remote-sensing missions that need stable power/thermal conditions. That's exactly why NASA's Pandora mission (launched on the Twilight rideshare in early 2026) targeted a dawn-dusk sun-synchronous orbit. Pandora uses a small telescope to study exoplanet atmospheres and host-star activity over long continuous observations. The orbit lets it avoid Earth-occultation interruptions and maintain steady pointing away from the Sun while collecting visible + near-infrared data on dozens of targets. In short: SSO = consistent local time over the ground; dawn-dusk SSO = "always in daylight" for the spacecraft itself.","sender":"AGENT","grokMode":"NORMAL","mediaUrls":[],"deepsearchHeaders":[{"header":"","steps":[{"finalMessage":"**","toolUsageCardResults":[{"toolUsageCardId":"950650f0-12d0-4474-8197-88640f3d161c"},{"toolUsageCardId":"911d8f6c-5dfa-45e1-bdd4-2a61eb35fca2"},{"toolUsageCardId":"e9fbd4c0-55bf-47b7-8d78-131ffcfbb429"},{"toolUsageCardId":"950650f0-12d0-4474-8197-88640f3d161c","webResults":[{"url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sun-synchronous_orbit","title":"Sun-synchronous orbit - Wikipedia","snippet":"A Sun-synchronous orbit (SSO), also called a heliosynchronous orbit, is a nearly polar orbit around a planet, in which the satellite passes over any given point of the planet's surface at the same local mean solar time. items.message:
**A Sun-synchronous orbit (SSO)** is a special type of **nearly polar orbit** (usually inclined around 97â€“99Â°) around Earth where a satellite passes over any given point on the planet's surface at roughly the **same local solar time** every day.

This happens because the orbital plane slowly precesses (rotates) eastward at about 1Â° per day â€” exactly matching the rate at which Earth orbits the Sun over the course of a year. As a result, the satellite's relationship to the Sun stays constant year-round, providing consistent lighting conditions underneath it.

### Why is this useful?
- **Earth-observing satellites** (weather, reconnaissance, Landsat, Sentinel) benefit from near-identical sunlight angles on every pass â†’ easier to compare images over time, detect changes, etc.
- Infrared or visible imaging gets reliable illumination without big seasonal variations in shadow or brightness.

### Dawn-dusk (or twilight) variant
Many SSOs are tuned to a **dawn-dusk configuration**, where the satellite crosses the equator near local sunrise or sunset (~6 AM or 6 PM local time). The spacecraft essentially "rides" along the **terminator** (the day-night boundary line).

Key advantages of this specific type:
- The satellite stays almost continuously in sunlight â†’ solar panels get near-constant power, with minimal or zero time in Earth's shadow (great for power-hungry payloads or missions avoiding eclipses).
- This is especially valuable for certain astronomy or remote-sensing missions that need stable power/thermal conditions.

That's exactly why NASA's **Pandora** mission (launched on the Twilight rideshare in early 2026) targeted a dawn-dusk sun-synchronous orbit. Pandora uses a small telescope to study exoplanet atmospheres and host-star activity over long continuous observations. The orbit lets it avoid Earth-occultation interruptions and maintain steady pointing away from the Sun while collecting visible + near-infrared data on dozens of targets.

In short: SSO = consistent local time over the ground; dawn-dusk SSO = "always in daylight" for the spacecraft itself.

Grok wrote a 10,000 word article about my career. 
It was 95% accurate.

But it got one big thing wrong. It said I got divorced. 
Truth is, I was never married. 

Instead of begging an anonymous editor to correct this, I highlighted the text and said: "Nuseir was never married."

This prompted Grok to do the most comprehensive online search I've ever seen. It watched hours of my content and transcribed it. Then it agreed with my suggestion and approved changes to my article instantly. 

Now I fully understand what @elonmusk refers to as the truth. It is not a marketing word. It is literally in the design of the system. 

Google needs to stop surfacing Wikipedia on the first page and replace it with Grokipedia asap.

Researcher. Advocate. Truth-teller.
Exposing failures in veteran care, courts & community systems

result.text:
Veterans Are Being Forced to Manipulate the System to Survive: Why a Federal Investigation into VA Community Care Is Now Mandatory (like the Somalian Day Care Scam)

Across the United States, a quiet but devastating pattern is emerging. Veterans in acute mental health crisis are deliberately avoiding the very system designed to serve them. Not because they want to but because they have learned, often the hard way, that seeking care through the Department of Veterans Affairs may result in delay, denial, or punishment rather than help.

Hospital clinicians, families, and veterans themselves report a growing trend: veterans in crisis traveling 100 miles or more to private facilities just to receive immediate treatment. This is not convenience-seeking behavior. It is system avoidance born of repeated failure.

What makes this alarming is not merely that itâ€™s happening but why it is happening.

A System That Requires â€œPermissionâ€ to Save YOUR Life

In civilian healthcare, insurance functions as a financial instrument, not a gatekeeper of autonomy. When someone has insurance, they choose their provider. When a home or vehicle is damaged, the insured selects the repair facility. Choice is fundamental.

Veterans, however, must navigate a labyrinth of referrals, approvals, and secondary authorizations, often during moments of crisis, to access non-VA care. Even then, approval is inconsistent, delayed, or denied outright.

This raises a serious question:

Why are veterans, who earned their benefits, treated as wards of a system rather than autonomous patients?

Community Care: Massive Funding, Minimal Accountability

At the center of this issue is the VA Community Care model.

Community Care facilities receive substantial federal funding, with many programs costing $30,000â€“$35,000 for 30-day placements. Yet reported success rates in some programs range from 1â€“3%, with limited longitudinal follow-up, minimal public reporting, and no standardized outcome auditing.

Despite this:

Funding continues to increase

Contracts are renewed

Oversight remains weak

Families and veterans report relapse, re-hospitalization, incarceration, or death within months of discharge

This pattern mirrors past federally funded failures, most notably recent childcare funding scandals, where money flowed freely without sufficient safeguards, outcome tracking, or enforcement mechanisms.

When public funds are allocated at this scale without transparency or measurable impact, investigation is no longer optional, it is mandatory.

The â€œPreferred Providerâ€ Problem: A Familiar Scam

Years ago, insurance companies were cited and penalized for steering policyholders to â€œpreferred repair centersâ€ that used inferior or used parts while billing for full repairs.

The parallel in veteran healthcare is impossible to ignore.

Veterans are being routed into preferred systems of care that:

Rely on outdated treatment models

Lack individualized trauma-informed approaches

Show poor long-term outcomes

Face little consequence for failure

What civilians would call unacceptable, veterans are expected to tolerate.

This is not innovation.

This is recycled care with a new label.

A Structural Conflict of Interest

The VA currently acts as:

1. Benefits administrator

2. Care provider

3. Referral authority

4. Oversight body

No other insurance system in the United States operates this way.

When the same entity controls funding, care delivery, and oversight, accountability collapses. Veterans are left without meaningful recourse, and families are left navigating crises without protection.

The VA should issue benefits, not dictate care.

Veterans should have the same right as any insured civilian to choose where and how they receive treatment, especially during medical emergencies.

Why a Federal Investigation Is Urgently Needed

This is not about isolated incidents. It is about systemic design failure.

A formal investigation must examine:

How Community Care funds are allocated

What outcome metrics are used (and which are ignored)

Why poor-performing programs continue to receive funding

Whether veterans are being deterred from or penalized for seeking private emergency care

Whether current policies violate basic standards of medical ethics and patient autonomy

When a system repeatedly produces harm, and resists reform, it must be externally examined.

Conclusion: This Is Not a Healthcare Issue. It Is a Civil Rights Issue.

Veterans are not asking for special treatment.

They are asking for equal treatment.

Equal access.

Equal choice.

Equal dignity.

A system that forces veterans to manipulate rules, travel extreme distances, or risk punishment just to survive is not broken. It is operating exactly as designed.

And that design now demands accountability.

It is time for a mandatory federal investigation into VA Community Care.

Lives depend on it.

result.text:
Let me get this straight:

> in 1913, the US passed the first income tax to fund ww1 as a "temporary measure"

> now, the US collects $2.5T of income tax/yr

> $1.5T of that money is spent on fraud, some of which directly undermines our republic or goes to illegal immigrants 

If we cut fraud and continue to collect tariffs, we could easily subsist on 0 or almost 0 income tax.

A nice thought to think about as we file our taxes this year and give the government half our paychecks. 

We've become so accustomed to this that most people don't realize the government was much smaller and much less corrupt when it didn't have this slush fund
